title: Early-Life Exposure to a Mixture of Phenols and Phthalates in Relation to Child Social Behavior: Applying an Evidence-Based Prioritization to a Cohort with Improved Exposure Assessment
abstract: Background: Previous studies aiming at relating exposure to phenols and phthalates with child social behavior characterized exposure using one or a few spot urine samples, resulting in substantial exposure misclassification. Moreover, early infancy exposure was rarely studied. Objectives: We aimed to examine the associations of phthalates and phenols with child social behavior in a cohort with improved exposure assessment and to  a priori  identify the chemicals supported by a higher weight of evidence. Methods: Among 406 mother–child pairs from the French Assessment of Air Pollution exposure during Pregnancy and Effect on Health (SEPAGES) cohort, 25 phenols/phthalate metabolites were measured in within-subject pools of repeated urine samples collected at the second and third pregnancy trimesters ( ∼ 21  samples/trimester) and at 2 months and 1-year of age ( ∼ 7  samples/period). Social behavior was parent-reported at 3 years of age of the child using the Social Responsiveness Scale (SRS). A structured literature review of the animal and human evidence was performed to prioritize the measured phthalates/phenols based on their likelihood to affect social behavior. Both adjusted linear regression and Bayesian Weighted Quantile Sum (BWQS) regression models were fitted. False discovery rate (FDR) correction was applied only to nonprioritized chemicals. Results: Prioritized compounds included bisphenol A, bisphenol S, triclosan (TCS), diethyl-hexyl phthalate ( Σ DEHP ), mono-ethyl phthalate (MEP), mono- n -butyl phthalate (MnBP), and mono-benzyl phthalate (MBzP). With the exception of bisphenols, which showed a mixed pattern of positive and negative associations in pregnant mothers and neonates, few prenatal associations were observed. Most associations were observed with prioritized chemicals measured in 1-y-old infants: Each doubling in urinary TCS ( β = 0.78 ; 95% CI: 0.00, 1.55) and MEP ( β = 0.92 ; 95% CI:  − 0.11 , 1.96) concentrations were associated with worse total SRS scores, whereas MnBP and  Σ DEHP  were associated with worse Social Awareness ( β = 0.25 ; 95% CI: 0.01, 0.50) and Social Communication ( β = 0.43 ; 95% CI:  − 0.02 , 0.89) scores, respectively. BWQS also suggested worse total SRS [ Beta 1 = 1.38 ; 95% credible interval (CrI):  − 0.18 , 2.97], Social Awareness ( Beta 1 = 0.37 ; 95% CrI: 0.06, 0.70), and Social Communication ( Beta 1 = 0.91 ; 95% CrI: 0.31, 1.53) scores per quartile increase in the mixture of prioritized compounds assessed in 1-y-old infants. The few associations observed with nonprioritized chemicals did not remain after FDR correction, with the exception of benzophenone-3 exposure in 1-y-old infants, which was suggestively associated with worse Social Communication scores (corrected  p = 0.07 ). Discussion: The literature search allowed us to adapt our statistical analysis according to the weight of evidence and create a corpus of experimental and epidemiological knowledge to better interpret our findings. Early infancy appears to be a sensitive exposure window that should be further investigated.  https://doi.org/10.1289/EHP11798

sections.title: Introduction
sections.text:
Neurobehavioral impairments, including autism spectrum disorders (ASDs), affect millions of children worldwide, are very costly, 1  and seem to be increasing in prevalence. 2  Subclinical symptoms are more frequent and also affect quality of life. Exposure to endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs) is among the suspected risk factors. 3

Phthalates and phenols are chemical families used as plasticizers, antimicrobials, and ultraviolet blockers in many everyday consumer products (e.g., plastic bottles, food containers, canned foods, personal care products, cosmetics, textiles), resulting in ubiquitous population exposure. 4 – 6  Some of them are recognized EDCs, capable of disrupting hormonal signaling (including estrogenic, anti-androgenic, and thyroid pathways among others) during critical periods, such as pregnancy and infancy. 7 , 8  Among other adverse outcomes, these EDCs can impact brain development and behavior in experimental animals, 9 – 12  and epidemiological evidence has begun to mount. 13 , 14  Although studies have investigated exposure to phenols and phthalates during pregnancy in relation to child autistic traits, 15 – 19  no study evaluated exposure during so-called mini-puberty. In humans, mini-puberty spans from birth to 6 months in males and until 2 years of age in females and has been recently identified as an important but understudied critical period for brain development. 20 , 21

Given the large within-day and within-week variability of phenol and phthalate urinary concentrations, accurate exposure characterization remains a major challenge. 22  Notably, exposure characterization using one spot urine sample leads to exposure misclassification and attenuation bias, that is, a bias toward null findings. 23 , 24

Another poorly addressed limitation is the management of the multiple comparison issue that often arises when investigating associations between multiple exposures and outcomes. Post hoc multiple-testing correction techniques are not always indicated and can even be counterproductive (especially for chemical compounds supported by experimental data) because they reduce type I error at the expense of increasing type II error. Therefore, some authors suggest to adapt the choice of adjusting or not for multiple comparisons to each exposure–outcome pair investigated. 25 , 26  In addition, a related concern is that mixture analyses frequently consider all chemicals measured in biospecimens, assuming a similar biological relevance; however, this may not be the case. Although this may constitute a good strategy when scarce toxicological/epidemiological evidence is available, using such an approximation could also increase noise or even lead to noncausal cancel-out effects. 27

The aims of this work were, first, to perform a structured comprehensive review of the  in vivo  toxicological and epidemiological literature to prioritize, among the phthalates and phenols assessed in our study, those with a higher weight of evidence (WoE) for an effect on social behavior. The second aim of this work was to rely on this prioritization to  a ) identify the associations that should be corrected or not for multiple comparisons in single-pollutant models and  b ) identify the most toxicologically relevant chemicals to be considered in a mixture model.

sections.title: Methods

We relied on previous toxicological and epidemiological studies to determine  a priori  whether adjustment for multiple comparisons was appropriate or not. Our underlying logic was that the need for multiple-testing correction is inversely proportional to the existing WoE for a given chemical–outcome pair. 25  Therefore, we performed a structured and comprehensive literature search in PubMed/MEDLINE, adapting the main points of the Navigation Guide systematic review methodology for environmental health studies. 28 , 29

First, the study question was defined: “Among the phenols and phthalates assessed in our study, what are those showing the highest strength of evidence regarding alterations in social behaviors?” Second, the participants, exposures, comparators, and outcomes (the PECO) were identified as follows:
 Participants: humans or animals, prioritizing exposure during preconception, pregnancy and infancy. Urine was prioritized as the exposure matrix. Exposures: phenols and phthalates frequently detected in mother’s and infant’s urine from the current Assessment of Air Pollution exposure during Pregnancy and Effect on Health Study (SEPAGES). Comparators: comparable groups of dosed animals or their tissues vs. those exposed to vehicle-only treatment. Comparable groups of human subjects exposed to higher vs. lower phenol/phthalate concentrations. Outcomes: neurodevelopmental outcomes, especially those closely related to the regulation of social, communicative, and repetitive behaviors.

Third, the evidence was selected executing the following search algorithm on 15 August 2021 and using the filters “Full-text” and “Abstract” availability:

(phthalate OR phthalic acid OR “Phthalic Acids”[nm] OR 1,2-Cyclohexane dicarboxylic acid diisononyl ester OR DINCH OR benzophenone-3 OR oxybenzone OR 2-Hydroxy-4-methoxybenzophenone OR triclosan OR methylparaben OR ethylparaben OR propylparaben OR butylparaben OR bisphenol A OR bisphenol S) AND (social OR social behavior OR repetitive behavior OR communication OR social responsiveness scale OR SRS OR autism OR autistic OR autistic traits OR asperger OR autism spectrum disorder OR neurodevelopment).

The bibliographic lists of the most recent reviews identified were hand-searched for additional studies. All titles and abstracts retrieved were screened by one author (V.M.) to determine eligibility based on inclusion criteria. A second author (C.P.) screened 25% of titles/abstracts for quality assurance. Studies were excluded if  a ) they were not related to the prespecified phenols/phthalates,  b ) they were not related to social behavior,  c ) there was no control group in animal studies, or  d ) they were not published in English. The selected studies were subjected to a study quality assessment and tabulated in an Excel database (see Supplemental Excel File), reporting study quality parameters, such as the following: study design; characteristics of the population, including sample or litter size; exposure assessment (biological matrix, number of biospecimens analyzed, timing of collection, chromatographic method, and quality assurance and quality control measures) or dose/route of administration; neuropsychological or behavioral test evaluated; statistical analysis and adjustment for confounders; and main results/effect estimates. Strengths and limitations of each study were also included.

A summary table was created ( Table 1 ), classifying the overall body of evidence for each chemical exposure as “limited,” “moderate,” or “supportive” evidence. Such classification was justified for each compound in the table considering  a ) the quantity and quality of  in vivo  and epidemiological evidence, and  b ) additional judgment and agreement between V.M. and C.P., including mechanistic evidence from previous reviews, evidence on other related neurobehavioral end points, consistency across species, and structural and toxicological analogy in the case of substitutes. This classification was then used to prioritize the chemicals for which a confirmatory or exploratory analysis would be performed. Associations for chemicals in the supportive evidence category were considered as confirmatory analyses and will not be corrected for multiple comparisons. In the case of “moderate” evidence, we justified the specific chemicals that were upgraded to confirmatory or downgraded to exploratory analyses. Associations for chemicals in the limited evidence category were considered as exploratory and will be corrected for multiple comparisons. Nevertheless, the “limited” category could be exceptionally upgraded to a confirmatory analysis if a high degree of consistency was observed across the limited evidence available together with other relevant criteria, such as structural and toxicological analogy to a chemical classified in the “supportive” category.

The SEPAGES cohort consists of 484 pregnant French women and their corresponding families recruited between 2014 and 2017 at eight obstetrical ultrasonography practices in the Grenoble metropolitan area. 30  Eligibility criteria included singleton pregnancies up to gestational week 19, being  > 18  years of age and affiliated to the French national security system, and planning to deliver in one of the four Grenoble maternity clinics. The present analysis included children with child social behavior assessed at 3 years of age and exposure biomarkers assessed in at least one of the following time windows (Figure S1): early pregnancy ( N = 406 ), late pregnancy ( N = 399 ), neonates ( N = 380 ), and infants ( N = 358 ). The SEPAGES cohort received approvals from the Ethics Committee (CPP) Sud-Est V and the National Commission on Informatics and Liberty (CNIL). Trained staff explained the study details to participants, and both prospective parents signed the written informed consent prior to inclusion.

Pregnant women were asked to collect three urine samples per day (morning, midday, and evening), for 7 consecutive d, twice during pregnancy: at the second trimester [median (25th percentile, 75th percentile) gestational  age = 17  (16–18) wk] and during the third trimester [33 (31–34) wk]. After birth, parents collected urine samples of their children by inserting a cotton gaze in diapers. For neonates [median (25th percentile, 75th percentile)  age = 8  (7, 11) wk] and infants [13.5 (13, 14) months], one urine sample per day for a week was collected. Pregnant women and their children showed excellent compliance: The median (25th percentile, 75th percentile) number of samples collected per pregnant woman at each collection week was 21 (20, 21) and 7 (6, 7) and 6 (5, 7) for neonates and infants, respectively. The families stored the urine samples in their freezers until the SEPAGES field workers picked them up at the end of each collection week and transported them to a certified biobank (ISO 9001 standard; Grenoble University Hospital; bb-0033-00069). For each of the four windows evaluated, within-subject weekly pools were then performed by combining equal volumes of all the samples obtained over a collection week (Figure S2).

In a previous study on bisphenol A (BPA) and triclosan (TCS), we demonstrated that correlations with the volume-weighted concentrations for all urine samples collected during a week (the gold standard), were similar for both equal- and unequal-volume pooling designs, supporting that accounting for urine volume when pooling was not necessary. 124  For example, when 10 samples were used to create the pools, the correlation with the gold standard was 0.97 for TCS and 0.75 for BPA with the equal-volume pool, compared with 0.98 and 0.70 for the volume-based pool. 124

Aliquots of weekly pools were then stored at  − 80 ° C  before being sent on dry ice with a temperature sensor to the Norwegian Institute of Public Health (Oslo, Norway), a certified European laboratory that has participated in recent interlaboratory comparisons. 125  The concentrations of 12 phenols and 12 phthalate and 2 nonphthalate plasticizer metabolites were measured in the urine samples (Table S1) using high-performance liquid chromatography coupled to mass spectrometry. 126 , 127  The phenols measured included methyl- (MEPA), ethyl- (ETPA), propyl- (PRPA), and butylparaben (BUPA), as well as bisphenols [BPA and bisphenol S (BPS), F (BPF), B (BPB), and AF (BPAF)] and benzophenone-3 (BP-3), TCS, and triclocarban (TCB). Phthalate metabolites included mono-ethyl phthalate (MEP), mono-isobutyl phthalate (MiBP), mono- n -butyl phthalate (MnBP), mono-benzyl phthalate (MBzP), and 6-hydroxy-mono-propyl-heptyl phthalate (ohMPHP); four di(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP) metabolites: mono(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (MEHP), mono(2-ethyl-5-hydroxyhexyl) phthalate (MEHHP), mono(2-ethyl-5-oxohexyl) phthalate (MEOHP), and mono(2-ethyl-5-carboxypentyl) phthalate (MECPP); and three di-isononyl phthalate (DiNP) metabolites: mono-hydroxy-isononyl phthalate (OH-MiNP), mono-oxo-isononyl phthalate (oxo-MiNP), and mono-carboxy-isononyl phthalate (cx-MiNP). Two metabolites of the plasticizer di(isononyl)cyclohexane-1,2-dicarboxylate (DINCH) were also measured: mono-hydroxy isononyl cyclohexane-1,2-dicarboxylate (OH-MiNCH) and mono-oxo isononyl cyclohexane-1,2-dicarboxylate (oxo-MiNCH). The limits of detection (LODs) and quantification (LOQs) ranged from 0.04 to  0.7 ng / mL  and from  0.10 to 2 ng / mL , respectively (Table S2). Owing to budget limitations, phthalate metabolites were assessed only in a subset of 152 neonates at 2 months of age, 128  and thus they were not considered in the present analysis.

In a previous work using data from this same cohort, total and free forms of phenol concentrations were measured to evaluate potential external contamination in a subset of 100 prenatal samples and all the neonatal and infant samples because they were at higher risk of contamination. Rolland et al. showed that no contamination was observed for prenatal samples, nor as for neonatal and infant samples, with the exception of BPA in neonates and infants, and MEPA in infants. 129  For these specific chemicals/periods, the present analysis used conjugated concentrations for associations reported in the main manuscript, whereas associations with both total and conjugated concentrations are reported in the Supplemental Material.

Child social behavior and autistic traits were evaluated at 3 years of age using the Social Responsiveness Scale, Second Edition (SRS-2). The SRS is a parent-reported 65-item questionnaire recognized as a valid and reliable quantitative measure of social impairment in both population and clinical settings. 130  It has good test–retest stability over time, parent–parent and parent–teacher interrater agreement, and discriminant and concurrent validity. 130  The SRS shows considerable agreement ( correlation = 0.7 ) with the Autism Diagnostic Interview-Revised (ADI-R), a gold standard for research diagnosis of ASD. 131

Each SRS item rates the frequency of a particular social behavior using a 4-point Likert scale, with higher scores indicating poorer social development. Items are grouped into five subscales: Social Awareness, Social Cognition, Social Communication, Social Motivation, and Restricted Interests and Repetitive Behaviors (RRBs). The SRS also provides a total SRS score (sum of the five subscales), which shows a good diagnostic potential for screening ASDs, 131  and the Social Communication and Interaction (SCI) score (sum of four subscales), which excludes the RRB subscale. In the present study population, we included only total SRS scores in the analysis and not the SCI score based on their very high correlation (Pearson’s  r > 0.98 ). Continuous raw scores were used.

A statistical plan was drafted, and submitted in advance to a registered public repository before analyses were performed ( https://osf.io/kxepb ).

TCB, BPAF, BPB, and BPF were quantified in  < 5 %  of the urine samples and were therefore excluded from further analyses. BUPA, quantified in 11%–25% of the samples, depending on the period, was also excluded. BPS was dichotomized as detected/quantified vs. nondetected. The remaining exposure biomarkers were detected in  ∼ 70 %  or more of the urine samples. In this later case, concentrations below the LOD and between the LOD and the LOQ were singly imputed by values randomly selected between 0 and the LOD and between the LOD and the LOQ, respectively, following the underlying distribution of concentrations. 132 , 133  This method has shown good performance when  < 30 %  of the data are below quantification limits. 133

When needed, the measured biomarker concentrations were standardized using a two-step approach to account for between-sample variations related to urine processing and chemical assay. 134 , 135  Three conditions were considered:  a ) time of sample transport from the participant’s home to the biobank,  b ) the time individual samples were kept at 4°C during the pooling procedure, and  c ) the analytical batches. Details can be consulted elsewhere. 111  Descriptive statistics were determined for both standardized and nonstandardized concentrations, comparing them using Spearman’s correlation coefficients. Standardized urinary biomarker concentrations were used in all exposure–outcome analyses.

For metabolites belonging to the same parent compound, molar sums (in micromoles per liter) were computed [i.e.,  Σ DEHP  (sum of MEHP, MEHHP, MEOHP, and MECPP),  Σ DiNP  (sum of OH-MiNP, oxo-MiNP, and cx-MiNP), and  Σ DINCH  (sum of OH-MiNCH and oxo-MiNCH)]. We also computed the molar sum of parabens [ Σ Parabens  (sum of MEPA, ETPA, and PRPA)] to limit the number of statistical tests.

For statistical analyses, exposure biomarkers were  log 2 - transformed  to reduce the skewness of distributions and the influence of extreme values.

Directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) were used to select adjustment variables based on  a priori  causal knowledge. 136  Models were controlled for covariates that may be a cause of the outcome without being a consequence of the exposure or a cause of both the outcome and exposure. 137  The main prenatal models were adjusted for maternal age (continuous), prepregnancy body mass index (BMI, continuous), education (below vs. master’s degree or above), anxiety/depression score at the third trimester (continuous, assessed using the Hospital Anxiety and Depression scale), 138  active smoking (smoker vs. nonsmoker), passive tobacco exposure (exposed vs. nonexposed), parity (nulliparous vs. uniparous/multiparous), mode of child care up to 1 year of age (day care vs. at home/others), family environment [continuous score, assessed using the Home Observation Measurement of the Environment (HOME)], 139  child sex (male/female), and child age (continuous) at SRS evaluation (Figure S3). Infant main models (Figure S4) were additionally adjusted for breast-feeding (lower vs. higher than a month). Regarding tobacco, neonatal models were adjusted for both maternal active and passive smoking, whereas 1-y-old–infant models were adjusted for maternal active smoking (as outcome predictor), and child passive smoking at 1 year of age (as potential confounder). Data on covariates were collected by self-administered questionnaires and questionnaires administered by a fieldworker during study visits.

Study participant covariates were described using measures of central tendency and dispersion for numerical variables and frequencies for categorical variables. Covariates between included and excluded participants were compared using the two-sample proportion test and the two-sample  t -test for categorical and continuous variables, respectively.

Missing covariate values were multiple imputed using chained equations (StataCorp). 140  Imputed data sets ( N = 20 ) were generated using linear and logistic regression methods for continuous and dichotomized variables, respectively (percentage of missing data was  < 15 % ). All variables considered in the final analyses (exposures, outcomes, and central covariates), as well as additional covariates included in sensitivity analyses, were included in the imputation model.

Linear regression models were separately fit for each exposure biomarker at each of the four time windows and each raw SRS score (the five subscales and the total score). Because coherence was observed between unadjusted and adjusted models, all subsequent analyses were run with covariate adjustment. For single-pollutant models, effect estimates ( β ) represented the adjusted mean difference for each doubling in standardized urinary exposure biomarkers. In the case of BPS (dichotomized), we report the  β  of the upper category compared with the lowest exposure category taken as reference.

Potential sex-specific associations were evaluated by including a product interaction term between child sex and exposure biomarker concentrations. A  p Interaction < 0.10  was considered as evidence of effect modification, 141  in which case, models were sex-stratified.

Phenols and phthalate metabolite concentrations were also categorized in quartiles and entered in the regression model as an ordinal level indicator in relation to total SRS scores. Effect estimates and  p Trend  across quartiles were checked for linearity.

False discovery rate (FDR) correction was applied only to exploratory associations, that is, associations with the nonprioritized compounds (those showing a limited WoE based on the  a priori  literature search).

We used adjusted Bayesian Weighted Quantile Sum (BWQS) regression to assess the association between phenols and phthalate metabolites, treated as a mixture, and social behavior. BWQS is a quantile-based approach that combines multiple independent variables additively into a weighted index, with weights estimating the contribution of each component to the mixture. Based on quantile transformations of the independent variables, it provides results that are insensitive to exposures outliers and skewed distributions. 142  This method constitutes a Bayesian extension of the WQS regression, 143  counteracting its main drawbacks, including higher stability of estimates, higher statistical power (no data splitting into training and validation sets), and avoiding the need to  a priori  select the directionality of the mixture association.

Exposure variables were modeled in quartiles. BWQS effect estimates (Beta1) are interpreted as the mean change in social behavior scores for each quartile increase in the mixture. We observed potential scale-reduction statistic (R-hat) values of  ∼ 1 , indicating optimal convergence of the Hamiltonian–Monte Carlo chain. BWQS models were performed running the 20 imputations for each mixture–outcome association, and regression estimates were pooled following Rubin’s rules. 144  We estimated the overall mixture association under two scenarios:  a ) considering only the prioritized chemicals with a higher WoE (main model), and  b ) all phenols and phthalate metabolites analyzed in single-pollutant models (secondary model). The relative weights of the components were shown only for the most relevant mixture associations.

The robustness of the main models was tested with additional covariates. Maternal and infant models were further adjusted for urine specific gravity (continuous, log-transformed; assessed in each weekly pool using a handheld Atago PAL 10-S refractometer) to rule out any potential influence of urine dilution 145 ; multivitamin intake at first trimester (yes/no), which may constitute both a source of MnBP/MEP and of beneficial nutrients for brain development 146 ; maternal employment at first trimester (yes/no) as a proxy for socioeconomic status; and breast-feeding ( < 1  vs.  > 1  month), which was not included in the main prenatal models because it could behave as a mediator. 147

For the main associations observed with molar sums ( Σ Parabens ,  Σ DEHP ,  Σ DiNP , and  Σ DINCH ), a sensitivity analysis was performed to assess the individual effect of each paraben or phthalate metabolite contained in the sum.

All tests were two-tailed and statistical significance was set as  p < 0.05 . A  p -value between 0.05 and 0.10 was considered as suggestive of an association. Nevertheless, results were interpreted considering patterns of associations, confidence intervals (CIs) and the prioritization of chemicals performed altogether, rather than considering solely statistical significance. 148  Regression analyses and multiple imputation were carried out with Stata (version 14.2; Stata Corp). BWQS was performed using the rstan package (bwqs function) in RStudio (version 4.0.3; RStudio Team).

sections.title: Study Population
sections.text: The SEPAGES cohort consists of 484 pregnant French women and their corresponding families recruited between 2014 and 2017 at eight obstetrical ultrasonography practices in the Grenoble metropolitan area. 30  Eligibility criteria included singleton pregnancies up to gestational week 19, being  > 18  years of age and affiliated to the French national security system, and planning to deliver in one of the four Grenoble maternity clinics. The present analysis included children with child social behavior assessed at 3 years of age and exposure biomarkers assessed in at least one of the following time windows (Figure S1): early pregnancy ( N = 406 ), late pregnancy ( N = 399 ), neonates ( N = 380 ), and infants ( N = 358 ). The SEPAGES cohort received approvals from the Ethics Committee (CPP) Sud-Est V and the National Commission on Informatics and Liberty (CNIL). Trained staff explained the study details to participants, and both prospective parents signed the written informed consent prior to inclusion.

sections.title: Repeated Urine Collection and Exposure Assessment
sections.text:
Pregnant women were asked to collect three urine samples per day (morning, midday, and evening), for 7 consecutive d, twice during pregnancy: at the second trimester [median (25th percentile, 75th percentile) gestational  age = 17  (16–18) wk] and during the third trimester [33 (31–34) wk]. After birth, parents collected urine samples of their children by inserting a cotton gaze in diapers. For neonates [median (25th percentile, 75th percentile)  age = 8  (7, 11) wk] and infants [13.5 (13, 14) months], one urine sample per day for a week was collected. Pregnant women and their children showed excellent compliance: The median (25th percentile, 75th percentile) number of samples collected per pregnant woman at each collection week was 21 (20, 21) and 7 (6, 7) and 6 (5, 7) for neonates and infants, respectively. The families stored the urine samples in their freezers until the SEPAGES field workers picked them up at the end of each collection week and transported them to a certified biobank (ISO 9001 standard; Grenoble University Hospital; bb-0033-00069). For each of the four windows evaluated, within-subject weekly pools were then performed by combining equal volumes of all the samples obtained over a collection week (Figure S2).

In a previous study on bisphenol A (BPA) and triclosan (TCS), we demonstrated that correlations with the volume-weighted concentrations for all urine samples collected during a week (the gold standard), were similar for both equal- and unequal-volume pooling designs, supporting that accounting for urine volume when pooling was not necessary. 124  For example, when 10 samples were used to create the pools, the correlation with the gold standard was 0.97 for TCS and 0.75 for BPA with the equal-volume pool, compared with 0.98 and 0.70 for the volume-based pool. 124

Aliquots of weekly pools were then stored at  − 80 ° C  before being sent on dry ice with a temperature sensor to the Norwegian Institute of Public Health (Oslo, Norway), a certified European laboratory that has participated in recent interlaboratory comparisons. 125  The concentrations of 12 phenols and 12 phthalate and 2 nonphthalate plasticizer metabolites were measured in the urine samples (Table S1) using high-performance liquid chromatography coupled to mass spectrometry. 126 , 127  The phenols measured included methyl- (MEPA), ethyl- (ETPA), propyl- (PRPA), and butylparaben (BUPA), as well as bisphenols [BPA and bisphenol S (BPS), F (BPF), B (BPB), and AF (BPAF)] and benzophenone-3 (BP-3), TCS, and triclocarban (TCB). Phthalate metabolites included mono-ethyl phthalate (MEP), mono-isobutyl phthalate (MiBP), mono- n -butyl phthalate (MnBP), mono-benzyl phthalate (MBzP), and 6-hydroxy-mono-propyl-heptyl phthalate (ohMPHP); four di(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP) metabolites: mono(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (MEHP), mono(2-ethyl-5-hydroxyhexyl) phthalate (MEHHP), mono(2-ethyl-5-oxohexyl) phthalate (MEOHP), and mono(2-ethyl-5-carboxypentyl) phthalate (MECPP); and three di-isononyl phthalate (DiNP) metabolites: mono-hydroxy-isononyl phthalate (OH-MiNP), mono-oxo-isononyl phthalate (oxo-MiNP), and mono-carboxy-isononyl phthalate (cx-MiNP). Two metabolites of the plasticizer di(isononyl)cyclohexane-1,2-dicarboxylate (DINCH) were also measured: mono-hydroxy isononyl cyclohexane-1,2-dicarboxylate (OH-MiNCH) and mono-oxo isononyl cyclohexane-1,2-dicarboxylate (oxo-MiNCH). The limits of detection (LODs) and quantification (LOQs) ranged from 0.04 to  0.7 ng / mL  and from  0.10 to 2 ng / mL , respectively (Table S2). Owing to budget limitations, phthalate metabolites were assessed only in a subset of 152 neonates at 2 months of age, 128  and thus they were not considered in the present analysis.

In a previous work using data from this same cohort, total and free forms of phenol concentrations were measured to evaluate potential external contamination in a subset of 100 prenatal samples and all the neonatal and infant samples because they were at higher risk of contamination. Rolland et al. showed that no contamination was observed for prenatal samples, nor as for neonatal and infant samples, with the exception of BPA in neonates and infants, and MEPA in infants. 129  For these specific chemicals/periods, the present analysis used conjugated concentrations for associations reported in the main manuscript, whereas associations with both total and conjugated concentrations are reported in the Supplemental Material.

sections.title: Outcome Assessment
sections.text:
Child social behavior and autistic traits were evaluated at 3 years of age using the Social Responsiveness Scale, Second Edition (SRS-2). The SRS is a parent-reported 65-item questionnaire recognized as a valid and reliable quantitative measure of social impairment in both population and clinical settings. 130  It has good test–retest stability over time, parent–parent and parent–teacher interrater agreement, and discriminant and concurrent validity. 130  The SRS shows considerable agreement ( correlation = 0.7 ) with the Autism Diagnostic Interview-Revised (ADI-R), a gold standard for research diagnosis of ASD. 131

Each SRS item rates the frequency of a particular social behavior using a 4-point Likert scale, with higher scores indicating poorer social development. Items are grouped into five subscales: Social Awareness, Social Cognition, Social Communication, Social Motivation, and Restricted Interests and Repetitive Behaviors (RRBs). The SRS also provides a total SRS score (sum of the five subscales), which shows a good diagnostic potential for screening ASDs, 131  and the Social Communication and Interaction (SCI) score (sum of four subscales), which excludes the RRB subscale. In the present study population, we included only total SRS scores in the analysis and not the SCI score based on their very high correlation (Pearson’s  r > 0.98 ). Continuous raw scores were used.

sections.title: Statistical Analysis
sections.text:
A statistical plan was drafted, and submitted in advance to a registered public repository before analyses were performed ( https://osf.io/kxepb ).

TCB, BPAF, BPB, and BPF were quantified in  < 5 %  of the urine samples and were therefore excluded from further analyses. BUPA, quantified in 11%–25% of the samples, depending on the period, was also excluded. BPS was dichotomized as detected/quantified vs. nondetected. The remaining exposure biomarkers were detected in  ∼ 70 %  or more of the urine samples. In this later case, concentrations below the LOD and between the LOD and the LOQ were singly imputed by values randomly selected between 0 and the LOD and between the LOD and the LOQ, respectively, following the underlying distribution of concentrations. 132 , 133  This method has shown good performance when  < 30 %  of the data are below quantification limits. 133

When needed, the measured biomarker concentrations were standardized using a two-step approach to account for between-sample variations related to urine processing and chemical assay. 134 , 135  Three conditions were considered:  a ) time of sample transport from the participant’s home to the biobank,  b ) the time individual samples were kept at 4°C during the pooling procedure, and  c ) the analytical batches. Details can be consulted elsewhere. 111  Descriptive statistics were determined for both standardized and nonstandardized concentrations, comparing them using Spearman’s correlation coefficients. Standardized urinary biomarker concentrations were used in all exposure–outcome analyses.

For metabolites belonging to the same parent compound, molar sums (in micromoles per liter) were computed [i.e.,  Σ DEHP  (sum of MEHP, MEHHP, MEOHP, and MECPP),  Σ DiNP  (sum of OH-MiNP, oxo-MiNP, and cx-MiNP), and  Σ DINCH  (sum of OH-MiNCH and oxo-MiNCH)]. We also computed the molar sum of parabens [ Σ Parabens  (sum of MEPA, ETPA, and PRPA)] to limit the number of statistical tests.

For statistical analyses, exposure biomarkers were  log 2 - transformed  to reduce the skewness of distributions and the influence of extreme values.

Directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) were used to select adjustment variables based on  a priori  causal knowledge. 136  Models were controlled for covariates that may be a cause of the outcome without being a consequence of the exposure or a cause of both the outcome and exposure. 137  The main prenatal models were adjusted for maternal age (continuous), prepregnancy body mass index (BMI, continuous), education (below vs. master’s degree or above), anxiety/depression score at the third trimester (continuous, assessed using the Hospital Anxiety and Depression scale), 138  active smoking (smoker vs. nonsmoker), passive tobacco exposure (exposed vs. nonexposed), parity (nulliparous vs. uniparous/multiparous), mode of child care up to 1 year of age (day care vs. at home/others), family environment [continuous score, assessed using the Home Observation Measurement of the Environment (HOME)], 139  child sex (male/female), and child age (continuous) at SRS evaluation (Figure S3). Infant main models (Figure S4) were additionally adjusted for breast-feeding (lower vs. higher than a month). Regarding tobacco, neonatal models were adjusted for both maternal active and passive smoking, whereas 1-y-old–infant models were adjusted for maternal active smoking (as outcome predictor), and child passive smoking at 1 year of age (as potential confounder). Data on covariates were collected by self-administered questionnaires and questionnaires administered by a fieldworker during study visits.

Study participant covariates were described using measures of central tendency and dispersion for numerical variables and frequencies for categorical variables. Covariates between included and excluded participants were compared using the two-sample proportion test and the two-sample  t -test for categorical and continuous variables, respectively.

Missing covariate values were multiple imputed using chained equations (StataCorp). 140  Imputed data sets ( N = 20 ) were generated using linear and logistic regression methods for continuous and dichotomized variables, respectively (percentage of missing data was  < 15 % ). All variables considered in the final analyses (exposures, outcomes, and central covariates), as well as additional covariates included in sensitivity analyses, were included in the imputation model.

Linear regression models were separately fit for each exposure biomarker at each of the four time windows and each raw SRS score (the five subscales and the total score). Because coherence was observed between unadjusted and adjusted models, all subsequent analyses were run with covariate adjustment. For single-pollutant models, effect estimates ( β ) represented the adjusted mean difference for each doubling in standardized urinary exposure biomarkers. In the case of BPS (dichotomized), we report the  β  of the upper category compared with the lowest exposure category taken as reference.

Potential sex-specific associations were evaluated by including a product interaction term between child sex and exposure biomarker concentrations. A  p Interaction < 0.10  was considered as evidence of effect modification, 141  in which case, models were sex-stratified.

Phenols and phthalate metabolite concentrations were also categorized in quartiles and entered in the regression model as an ordinal level indicator in relation to total SRS scores. Effect estimates and  p Trend  across quartiles were checked for linearity.

False discovery rate (FDR) correction was applied only to exploratory associations, that is, associations with the nonprioritized compounds (those showing a limited WoE based on the  a priori  literature search).

We used adjusted Bayesian Weighted Quantile Sum (BWQS) regression to assess the association between phenols and phthalate metabolites, treated as a mixture, and social behavior. BWQS is a quantile-based approach that combines multiple independent variables additively into a weighted index, with weights estimating the contribution of each component to the mixture. Based on quantile transformations of the independent variables, it provides results that are insensitive to exposures outliers and skewed distributions. 142  This method constitutes a Bayesian extension of the WQS regression, 143  counteracting its main drawbacks, including higher stability of estimates, higher statistical power (no data splitting into training and validation sets), and avoiding the need to  a priori  select the directionality of the mixture association.

Exposure variables were modeled in quartiles. BWQS effect estimates (Beta1) are interpreted as the mean change in social behavior scores for each quartile increase in the mixture. We observed potential scale-reduction statistic (R-hat) values of  ∼ 1 , indicating optimal convergence of the Hamiltonian–Monte Carlo chain. BWQS models were performed running the 20 imputations for each mixture–outcome association, and regression estimates were pooled following Rubin’s rules. 144  We estimated the overall mixture association under two scenarios:  a ) considering only the prioritized chemicals with a higher WoE (main model), and  b ) all phenols and phthalate metabolites analyzed in single-pollutant models (secondary model). The relative weights of the components were shown only for the most relevant mixture associations.

The robustness of the main models was tested with additional covariates. Maternal and infant models were further adjusted for urine specific gravity (continuous, log-transformed; assessed in each weekly pool using a handheld Atago PAL 10-S refractometer) to rule out any potential influence of urine dilution 145 ; multivitamin intake at first trimester (yes/no), which may constitute both a source of MnBP/MEP and of beneficial nutrients for brain development 146 ; maternal employment at first trimester (yes/no) as a proxy for socioeconomic status; and breast-feeding ( < 1  vs.  > 1  month), which was not included in the main prenatal models because it could behave as a mediator. 147

For the main associations observed with molar sums ( Σ Parabens ,  Σ DEHP ,  Σ DiNP , and  Σ DINCH ), a sensitivity analysis was performed to assess the individual effect of each paraben or phthalate metabolite contained in the sum.

All tests were two-tailed and statistical significance was set as  p < 0.05 . A  p -value between 0.05 and 0.10 was considered as suggestive of an association. Nevertheless, results were interpreted considering patterns of associations, confidence intervals (CIs) and the prioritization of chemicals performed altogether, rather than considering solely statistical significance. 148  Regression analyses and multiple imputation were carried out with Stata (version 14.2; Stata Corp). BWQS was performed using the rstan package (bwqs function) in RStudio (version 4.0.3; RStudio Team).

sections.text:
Of the 821 publications identified, 34  in vivo  toxicological and 37 epidemiological studies were selected (Figure S5) and tabulated in detail (Supplemental Excel File).  Table 1  provides an evidence-based summary of the animal and human studies retrieved for each chemical, together with additional  in vitro, in vivo , or review works that contributed to formulate the WoE (limited, moderate, or supportive), its gradings (i.e., upgrade/downgrade decisions), and the justification of decisions. The search prioritized BPA, BPS, TCS,  Σ DEHP , MEP, MnBP, and MBzP. For these prioritized compounds, associations will not be corrected for multiple comparisons, in contrast to the remaining chemicals (BP-3,  Σ Parabens , MiBP, ohMPHP,  Σ DiNP , and  Σ DINCH ;  Table 1 ).

SEPAGES mothers were highly educated (58% reached a master’s degree or higher), presented an overall healthy BMI ( mean ± SD = 
 22.3 ± 3.8 kg / m 2 ), and conceived at a  mean ± SD  age of 32.6 (3.9) y ( Table 2 ). Approximately half (46%) of the mothers were nulliparous at the time of conception, most of them (91%) breast-fed their infant for  > 1  month, and there was a greater number of boys (54%) born in the cohort. Maternal active smoking at pregnancy was infrequent (7%) compared with data from France, 123  whereas approximately one of five pregnant mothers and infants were exposed to secondhand tobacco smoke. Children were on average 3 years of age ( mean ± SD = 
 37.1 ± 1.1  months) at completion of the SRS questionnaire. Total SRS scores ranged between 4 and 100, with a  mean ± SD  of 28.9 (13.5) points, and only three children (0.74%) had a score  ≥ 70  raw points, the cutoff for a higher risk of ASD over childhood. 130  Mothers excluded from the present analysis were slightly younger, less educated, more likely to breast-feed their infants for  < 1  month, and presented higher anxiety and depression scores ( Table 2 ).

sections.title: Evidence from the Literature and Prioritization
sections.text: Of the 821 publications identified, 34  in vivo  toxicological and 37 epidemiological studies were selected (Figure S5) and tabulated in detail (Supplemental Excel File).  Table 1  provides an evidence-based summary of the animal and human studies retrieved for each chemical, together with additional  in vitro, in vivo , or review works that contributed to formulate the WoE (limited, moderate, or supportive), its gradings (i.e., upgrade/downgrade decisions), and the justification of decisions. The search prioritized BPA, BPS, TCS,  Σ DEHP , MEP, MnBP, and MBzP. For these prioritized compounds, associations will not be corrected for multiple comparisons, in contrast to the remaining chemicals (BP-3,  Σ Parabens , MiBP, ohMPHP,  Σ DiNP , and  Σ DINCH ;  Table 1 ).

sections.title: Characteristics of the Study Population
sections.text:
SEPAGES mothers were highly educated (58% reached a master’s degree or higher), presented an overall healthy BMI ( mean ± SD = 
 22.3 ± 3.8 kg / m 2 ), and conceived at a  mean ± SD  age of 32.6 (3.9) y ( Table 2 ). Approximately half (46%) of the mothers were nulliparous at the time of conception, most of them (91%) breast-fed their infant for  > 1  month, and there was a greater number of boys (54%) born in the cohort. Maternal active smoking at pregnancy was infrequent (7%) compared with data from France, 123  whereas approximately one of five pregnant mothers and infants were exposed to secondhand tobacco smoke. Children were on average 3 years of age ( mean ± SD = 
 37.1 ± 1.1  months) at completion of the SRS questionnaire. Total SRS scores ranged between 4 and 100, with a  mean ± SD  of 28.9 (13.5) points, and only three children (0.74%) had a score  ≥ 70  raw points, the cutoff for a higher risk of ASD over childhood. 130  Mothers excluded from the present analysis were slightly younger, less educated, more likely to breast-feed their infants for  < 1  month, and presented higher anxiety and depression scores ( Table 2 ).

SRS score ranges were: total SRS (4–100 points), Social Awareness (0–15 points), Social Cognition (0–15 points), Social Communication (0–39 points), Social Motivation (0–19 points), and RRB (0–18 points).

With the exception of BPS (detected in between 26% and 70% of the samples, according to the exposure window) and BUPA (quantified in 9% and 25% of samples), the remaining phenols, phthalates, and DINCH metabolites were detected and quantified in most samples (Table S2). Spearman correlations between standardized and measured concentrations were  > 0.80  for all compounds considered in the analysis (Table S3), indicating a limited influence of urine processing and assay batch conditions. Phenols presented low correlations ( r < 0.4 ) among them at all windows examined (Figures S6 and S7). Phthalate metabolites, especially MEP, MnBP, MiBP, MBzP,  Σ DEHP ,  Σ DiNP , and ohMPHP showed moderate correlations ( r = 0.4 – 0.6 ) at all windows, being strongest ( > 0.6 ) in infancy (Figure S7).

sections.title: Discussion
sections.text:
In this cohort relying on within-subject pools of multiple urine biospecimens to improve exposure characterization during pregnancy, neonatal, and infancy periods, we observed several associations between specific phenols and phthalates and worse social behavior scores at 3 years of age, with most of these associations corresponding to an increased population risk of ASD in children.

Results of both single- and multipollutant models highlight early infancy as the most sensitive window of exposure for altered social behavior, although some associations were also observed at other time windows in single-pollutant models. Social awareness and communication were the skills most clearly affected by infant exposure to phenols and phthalates. The following factors could explain the heightened susceptibility observed for infants. First, infant exposure patterns may differ from those of pregnant women, with dust and toys constituting differential exposure sources coupled to frequent hand-to-mouth behaviors. 149 – 152  Second, detoxification pathways are immature in neonates and infants, possibly leading to increased EDC blood levels for longer periods. 153  Finally, the transition from crawling to walking at  ∼ 1  year of age is linked to important advances in social and language development. 154  At the public health level, our results showed that infants in the highest quartile of the prioritized mixture showed an average increase of  ∼ 4  points in the total SRS scale, which is substantial, knowing that exposure to these chemicals is widespread and that even slight shifts in the population distribution of social symptoms could result in a nonnegligible excess of children entering borderline or clinical ASD diagnoses. 155 , 156  Future studies investigating EDC exposure at early infancy are needed to confirm our results.

The toxicological evidence retrieved from our literature search identified several modes of action through which phenols and phthalates may alter social behavior including estrogenic (BPA, BPS, TCS, MEP, BP-3, and parabens), anti-androgenic (BPA, MnBP, MBzP, DEHP, DiNP, and MiBP), thyroid (TCS, DEHP, and BPA), retinoic acid (TCS), gut microbiota (TCS and BPA), and vasopressin/oxytocin pathways (BPA and DEHP), among others ( Table 1 ; Supplemental Excel File). Consequently, the infant mixture association observed could be the result of additive effects resulting from both similar and dissimilar modes of action. This mixture effect is supported by rodent studies demonstrating impairments in social behavior after gestational/lactational exposure to mixtures of phthalates containing between 3 and 6 of the phthalates investigated, 41 , 72 , 73  and particularly by Repouskou et al. 41  and Caporale et al., 157  who followed a human-to-laboratory approach, testing doses of phthalates and BPA found in humans on social behavior in rodents and in ASD-related pathways in human brain organoids, respectively. Although the need to evaluate the risk of co-occurring chemical families, such as phenols and phthalates is clear, regulation of chemical mixtures is still lagging. 158

Most single-pollutant linear associations were observed for prioritized compounds ( ∼ 68 %  of associations with  p < 0.05  and  ∼ 71 %  of associations with  p < 0.10  in the whole population; Tables S5 and S9). Similarly, most patterns of associations were also observed for prioritized chemicals.

Regarding bisphenols, neonatal exposure to both BPA and BPS showed protective associations with social behavior. These results were in line with the suggestive protective association observed for BPA at T2, but not with the deleterious association observed at T3 for BPA in girls and BPS in the whole sample. Although there is strong toxicological evidence for the effects of BPA on social behavior ( Table 1 ), our results suggest a complex interplay for bisphenols depending on the window of exposure and sex. Sex-specific associations have been previously reported for BPA, with two epidemiological studies showing poorer social performance among girls, 54 , 55  although another reported such an association in boys. 19  Prenatal BPA levels in our cohort ranged from 1.8 to  2.6 ng / mL , not differing from previous prenatal cohorts reporting associations with child SRS scores (range:  0.8 – 2 ng / mL ). 18 , 19 , 54 , 55

The only other epidemiological study that assessed BPS reported, like us, a moderate frequency of detection: 58% in Liu et al., 57  vs. 26%–70% in our study, depending on the exposure window. The study by Liu et al., reported no clear association between second trimester urinary BPS concentrations and socioemotional scores at 2 years of age. 57  Although a suggestive interaction ( p = 0.09 ) between BPS and sex was observed for this subscale, the authors did not stratify the models. 57  Thus, the deleterious association observed at T3 in our study needs further investigation because rodent studies have suggested poorer social interaction, along with increased anxiety and aggressive behavior, 30 , 65 , 66  after prenatal and lactational exposure to BPS.

TCS exposure can trigger autism-like phenotypes in rodents, 102 , 105 , 159  through different modes of action, including altered retinoic acid signaling and changes in gut microbiota ( Table 1 ). Our study suggested that infant TCS exposure predicted poorer social behavior in general, including repetitive behaviors, a cornerstone of autistic traits. In addition, both neonates and infant TCS exposure was associated with more social awareness problems in boys, whereas no clear pattern of association was observed during pregnancy for this compound. Although a large Canadian study did not find prenatal associations with child autistic traits, 106  a French cohort reported decreased prosocial behavior in boys. 58  Regarding postnatal exposure, a Chinese cohort reported that TCS exposure at 3 years of age—but not at pregnancy—was cross-sectionally associated with poorer social scores at 3 years of age. 108  When these children were 10 y old, a suggestive prenatal association between TCS and poorer prosocial scores was also observed. 107  Altogether, TCS exposure may be a risk factor contributing to child autistic traits that should be further investigated.

Regarding prioritized phthalates, MEP at T2 showed a nonlinear positive association with total SRS scores peaking at the second quartile. At T3, higher MEP concentrations were associated with social communication problems but only among girls. At Y1, MEP was associated with higher total SRS scores. These results for the prenatal windows are, overall, consistent with the available toxicological and epidemiological evidence ( Table 1 ). Thus, prenatal exposure to MEP has been associated with worse social behavior or ASD-spectrum in several studies, 17 , 18 , 74 , 77 , 79 – 81  although others reported null 16  or inverse associations. 15  Even though the human evidence converges in a similar direction, additional toxicological studies are needed to support the association between MEP and worse child social performance.

MnBP is a known anti-androgenic chemical ( Table 1 ). Although no association was seen for this compound at T2, MnBP at T3 showed a nonlinear association with higher total SRS scores, together with an association with higher social communication problems in girls. At Y1, the fourth quartile of MnBP was associated with higher total SRS scores, in addition to a linear association with more social awareness problems. Pregnancy MnBP exposure has been linked to child social problems in several studies, supporting the associations observed in this work for the prenatal window, 15 , 17 , 18 , 74 , 79 , 81  although three small cohorts reported null results. 56 , 74 , 77  Kim et al. reported a positive association between MnBP exposure at 4 years of age—but not at pregnancy—and social problems in late childhood. 75

We observed few deleterious associations with MBzP. These associations were observed at the 1-y window, limiting comparisons with previous studies that assessed only prenatal exposure. That being said, of the cohorts that investigated prenatal MBzP exposure in relation to SRS scores, a large cohort identified MBzP as the primary driver of an association with a mixture of phthalates. 17  Another three cohorts showed significant or suggestive associations in the same direction, 15 , 74  suggesting overall that MBzP may be a contributor to child autistic traits, although additional toxicological and epidemiological data are needed to achieve a higher degree of confidence.

DEHP has been shown to affect social behavior in rodents, as well as in some epidemiological studies ( Table 1 ). Notwithstanding, we observed a few associations that were either nonlinear (association with total score at T2) or borderline significant (association with social communication problems at Y1). Although  in vivo  toxicological studies support an effect of DEHP on social behavior, 70 , 71  the epidemiological literature has shown mixed results, with some prenatal cohorts reporting positive, 74 – 76  null, 17 , 56 , 77 , 78  or negative 74  associations with SRS scores. Because prenatal DEHP concentrations in our study (range:  32.8 – 33.6 ng / mL ) were similar and higher to other cohorts reporting associations between prenatal DEHP exposure and child SRS scores (range:  15 – 32 ng / mL ), 74 – 76  the differences in results are not explained by differences in exposure levels.

The single-pollutant associations observed with nonprioritized chemicals should be interpreted with caution, given that for these chemicals the WoE was quite limited, and most associations did not remain after correction for multiple comparisons.

BP-3 was the unique nonprioritized chemical that still showed a suggestive association with social problems after FDR correction. Some consistency across windows was also observed: BP-3 concentrations at Y1 were associated with higher total SRS scores, together with nonlinear positive associations observed at both T2 and T3 windows. BP-3 is estrogenic and anti-androgenic at relatively low doses and has been linked to altered expression of estrogenic receptors in the rodent brain at moderate doses. 116  This chemical was not prioritized because of the lack of animal studies investigating effects on social behavior and the limited number of human studies—only two studies—and those showed mixed findings. 58 , 107  Additional toxicological and epidemiological studies are needed to confirm our results.

Exposure to phenols and phthalates has been linked to sex-specific neurodevelopmental effects in both experimental animals and humans. 14 , 160  The prevalence of ASD is about four times higher in boys than girls worldwide, linked to sex-differential genetic and hormonal factors. 161 , 162  In the present work, a clear sex-specific pattern of associations emerged at T3, with girls showing more social communication problems in response to the prioritized chemicals BPA, MEP, and MnBP. Interestingly, this pattern is coherent with a previous SEPAGES analysis reporting that prenatal exposure to a mixture of phenols and phthalates led by BPA, MEP, MnBP, and MBzP was associated with poorer externalizing and internalizing behaviors among girls at 2 years of age. 111  Other studies also reported an association between prenatal and childhood exposure to BPA and more social problems among girls, 54 , 55 , 59  and between prenatal MEP exposure and more social symptoms in girls. 56  The fact that some studies tended to observe more associations in girls, whereas other studies tended to observe more associations in boys may be the result of how chemicals and their mixtures interfere with hormonal regulation (especially estrogen-to-androgen balance) at specific periods of brain development. 20 , 160

We observed few other sex-specific associations, but in most cases, they were isolated and only for SRS subscales.

Among the strengths of this work is the within-subject pooling of multiple repeated urine samples, which was designed to reduce exposure misclassification and attenuation bias. 24  Previous risk assessment panels excluded observational exposure–outcome studies based on exposure misclassification concerns for nonpersistent chemicals, such as BPA. 13  Our work counteracted this limitation, presenting a higher potential for regulatory uptake. The SEPAGES design allowed us to investigate exposure not only during pregnancy but also in neonates and infants, producing new and relevant data during this understudied period. Another strength was the implementation of a novel mixture model (namely, BWQS), that counteracted some of the WQS limitations, providing higher power and stability of estimates, and avoiding the need to  a priori  assume the directionality of the mixture. 142

Based on the Navigation Guide systematic review methodology, 29  we were able to prioritize the phenols and phthalates with the highest WoE for an effect on social behavior before executing the statistical analyses. This allowed us to decide whether a multiple comparisons correction was indicated or not for each exposure-outcome pair examined. Interestingly, in single-pollutant models, most patterns of associations were observed for the prioritized compounds. Although mixture approaches help to counteract the multiple comparison issue, 163  risk assessment continues to mostly rely on single chemicals, and therefore both single-pollutant and mixture models are needed and complementary. Moreover, the application of our evidence-based prioritization to the mixture analysis also revealed that the mixture effect seemed to be driven by prioritized chemicals, given that the prioritized model provided similar and even strengthened estimates compared with the overall mixture. Because the inclusion of chemicals with uncertain or limited weights of evidence may increase noise or even lead to noncausal cancel-out effects, 27  the need for prioritization in mixture analyses may be directly proportional to the number of chemicals investigated. The literature search also resulted in a comprehensive corpus of mechanistic,  in vivo , and observational evidence specifically related to social behavior that helped to interpret our findings and identify data gaps. Indeed, the knowledge and prioritization generated may be useful for future studies in the field, and researchers should consider the need to prioritize their analyses based on study design, the number of comparisons made, and the WoE available for the chemical families under study. Admittedly, the implementation of an evidence-based prioritization is not applicable to all contexts, requiring:  a ) a sufficient quantity and quality of evidence on the exposures investigated, and  b ) a reproducible and valid prioritization given that this step will partly determine the interpretation of results. A shortcoming of our prioritization strategy is that novel chemicals are more likely to be classified as nonprioritized compounds just due to limited data availability. This aspect should be considered when judging the evidence, as was exemplified with BPS (limited evidence, but prioritized based on structural,  in vitro , and  in vivo  analogy with BPA). Further, the main limitation of our evidence-based prioritization (possible underestimation of true associations for novel chemicals) will tend to self-correct over time in parallel to the generation of new evidence.

Other limitations include the medium size of our cohort, particularly when facing sex-stratified analyses. However, our improved exposure assessment is anticipated to substantially increase the statistical power compared with similar-sized cohorts collecting few urine samples. 23  Owing to budget limitations, phthalate metabolites could not be assessed in all neonatal urine samples, resulting in an incomplete comparison with the remaining windows. Although not a limitation because representativeness is a not an essential element in etiologic studies, 164  it should be kept in mind that SEPAGES mothers were highly educated and healthy, meaning that the observed associations could differ (possibly being stronger) 165  in populations with a lower socioeconomic status. On the other hand, the homogeneity of our population limited the potential for confounding bias.

In conclusion, the present work developed a prioritization strategy based on previous toxicological and epidemiological studies, which helped to manage the issue of multiple comparisons, as well as to define a toxicologically relevant mixture. Infant exposure to a mixture of the prioritized endocrine disruptors BPA, TCS, MEP, MnBP, MBzP, and DEHP was associated with worse social behavior at 3 years of age. The novel associations observed suggest that early infancy—the period at which children begin to communicate and interact with peers—represents a critical window of vulnerability for child social development that should be further investigated.
